item.title: Predicate
item.description: Abstract Â§ Also known as Propositional Functions & Open Sentences Example: let P stand for is a student at NUS, then P(x) = x is a student at NUS, where x is the Variable, P is the Symbol Truth value depends on Variable Becomes a Mathematical Statement when specific values are substituted for Variable Returns either true or false, thus cant be used as a Variable that is substituted into Symbol like P() Made of Symbol & finite number of Variable Terminologies Â§ Variable Â§ Holds value that determines if Predicate is true or false It doesn't hold the value of true or false! Only Mathematical Statement can be true or false Symbol Â§ Represents a property or relation Quantifiers Â§ Instead of manually assign a specific value to Variable to obtain a Mathematical Statement Quantifiers is another way, specific how many of a particular type of values that make the predicate true âˆ€ âˆƒ Order of Quantifiers Â§ Unless the Quantifiers are of the same type.

item.title: Mathematical Statement
item.description: Abstract Â§ Also known as Proposition 3 important types are Universal, Conditional & Existential We can form statements that are Universal & Conditional, or more to form complex statements Either True or False Warning Doesnâ€™t depend on any Variable, unless it is Logical Equivalence equation Not in a question form Different Types of Statements Â§ Universal Â§ Made of Symbol, Variable & Quantifiers âˆ€xâˆˆD,Q(x) true iff Q(x) is true for every x in D false iff Q(x) is false for at least one x in D For simple ones, usually universal comes with Conditional Statement Existential Â§ Made of Symbol, Variable & Quantifiers âˆƒxâˆˆD,Q(x) true iff Q(x) is true for at least one x in D false iff Q(x) is false for all x in D For simple ones, usually existential comes with Conjunction Negation of Universal Â§ Logical Equivalence to Existential There is AT LEAST ONE that IS NOT Â¬(âˆ€xâˆˆD,Q(x))â‰¡âˆƒxâˆˆD,Â¬Q(x) Negation of Existential Â§ Logical Equivalence to Universal ALL ARE NOT Â¬(âˆƒxâˆˆD,Q(x))â‰¡âˆ€xâˆˆD,Â¬Q(x) Negation of Universal Conditional Â§ Make use of Negation of Universal & Implication Law Universal Conditional Â§ Made of Symbol, Variable & Quantifiers & Conditional Statement âˆ€x(ifP(x)â†’Q(x)) Can be simplified to Universal âˆ€xâˆˆP,Q(x) Conditional Â§ Conditional Statement Ifâ€¦, thenâ€¦ Terminologies Â§ Statement Â§ A sentence that is True or False, but not both Can be presented with variables like p, q, r & s etc Logical Connectives Â§ Negation: NOT performed first Disjunction: OR ,Conjunction: AND coequal, make sure proper parentheses is used to avoid Ambiguous If-then/implies: performed last, coequal with iff Statement/Propositional Form Â§ Make up with Statement variables & Logical Connectives Compound Statement Â§ Make up with Statement variables & Logical Connectives When the statement has Conditional Statement, convert it using Implication Law to make it much less confusing Tautology t Â§ Statement/Propositional Form that is always true Contradiction c Â§ Statement/Propositional Form that is always false Implicitly Quantified Â§ The Quantifiers are assumed without specified explicitly Vacuous Truth of Universal Â§ Given the statement: All balls in the bowl are blue, however no balls in the bowl.

item.title: Second Brain for CS
item.description: Navigation Â§ Homepage is still under development. You can navigate around the notes using the explorer on the left side or visit the list of tags that categories the notes.

item.title: MIPS R-Type Instruction
item.description: Abstract Â§ Opcode is always 000000 Operation is decided by the Function Code 6 parts - Opcode, Source Register, Target Register, Destination Register, Shift Amount & Function Code Terminologies Â§ Function Code Â§ 6 bits Give MIPS (2^6-1) + 2^6 = 127 instead of 2^6=64 Instruction Dedicated for MIPS R-Type Instruction (if my understanding isnâ€™t wrong) Shift Amount Â§ 5bits Labeled as shamt .

item.title: MIPS Instruction
item.description: Abstract Â§ The Instruction may specify 3 Registers - Destination Register, Source Register & Target Register Terminologies Â§ Destination Register Â§ 5bits Labeled rd, mapped to WR Registers that gets the result of Operation in MIPS R-Type Instruction Instruction Source Register Â§ 5bits Labeled rs, mapped to RR1 Register with value stored that we want to use to carry out Operation Target Register Â§ 5 bits Labeled rt, mapped to RR2 Register with value stored we want to use in MIPS R-Type Instruction Register that gets the result of Operation in MIPS I-Type Instruction .

item.title: GPU
item.description: Abstract Â§ A Multi-core chips with thousands of tiny cores Benefits Â§ Optimised for Parallel Computing Â§ Allows games to perform a ton of Linear Algebra in parallel Â§ We can calculate pixels in batches or parallel Great for AI related work Â§ Allow training Deep Learning Models that perform tons Matrix Multiplication on dataset Cons Â§ Hard to program Â§ Comparison with CPU Â§ CPU one core is way more power, and able to handle complication logics like Branching.

item.title: Dynamic Programming

item.title: MacOs Setup
item.description: Abstract Â§ Note ğŸŒŸ denotes tools & settings I must have in MacOS to have a smooth user/developer experience GUI Apps Â§ Install Firefox (Replaced with floorp) ğŸŒŸ Install Bypass Paywalls Install Dropbox Install Obsidian ğŸŒŸ Install Keypass (Replaced with Install StrongBox from App Store) ğŸŒŸ Install VSC ğŸŒŸ Add code into cli Install Termius ğŸŒŸ Modify Default Shell Install Tutanota ğŸŒŸ Install Notion ğŸŒŸ Install Docker (Replaced with OrbStack) ğŸŒŸ Install Podman Install Node Version Manager, npm included ğŸŒŸ Install Postman Install GitKraken ğŸŒŸ Install Brave Install MySQL Workbench Install Google Drive Client ğŸŒŸ Install Java JDK ğŸŒŸ Install IntelliJ Community ğŸŒŸ Install VirtualBox Install Ngrok # Move Ngrok Executable to PATH cp ngrok /Users/<USERNAME>/.

item.title: 4. Try describing 1 object 2 ways
item.description: #problem_solving Note Basically explaining something in 2 different perspectives. For example, counting the possible permutation of a string of 5bits.
